alert.note: Alert for Sandoval (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 13 at 7:02PM MDT until April 18 at 8:55AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Mexico... Jemez River Above Jemez Pueblo affecting Sandoval County. .Warm temperatures continue to cause rapid melting of snowpack, causing increased river flows. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL TUESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor to moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Jemez River above Jemez Pueblo. * WHEN...Until Tuesday morning. * IMPACTS...With a river stage between 7 and 8 feet, multiple locations along highway 4 between San Ysidro and Jemez Springs will see water crossing the road from tributaries and low water crossing points. The Wastewater Treatment plant 1 mile downstream of Jemez Springs can be impacted between 7 and 7.7 feet. Water will be on Highway 4 at mile marker 1, 2 and 33. Homes near the river in San Ysidro could also be impacted. At a river flood stage of 8.0 feet, significant overbank flows will occur from above Jemez Springs down through the Jemez Pueblo. Further rises will result in bridges becoming unsafe to cross in and around Jemez Springs. At a river flood stage of 10.0 feet, widespread overbank flooding will occur. Bridges in and around Jemez Springs will become either impassable or unsafe to cross due to the high water and debris caught up in the fast flow. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:45 AM MDT Thursday the stage was 7.8 feet. - Forecast...The river will oscillate around flood stage with a maximum value ranging between 8 and 10 feet. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 8.8 feet on 09/28/1990. - http://www.weather.gov/abq/EmergencyPrepFlood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Walking near riverbanks is highly discouraged. To escape rising water, take the shortest path to higher ground. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/abq. The next statement will be issued Friday morning around 915 AM MDT.
